instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
threads.message:
The board just stop work.
F4700 = 5.2V
F7140 (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) = 0.23V - DIODE MODE = 0.424
L7130 = DIODE MODE 0.415

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
threads.message: Voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>? 5.2 volts is your problem NOT PPBUS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>/P, <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>.
Check diode mode on power pins of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Inspect under microscope if any of these chips has some very small hole on it.

Also look with atention at redriver circuit.
Is on the oposite side of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips, near the USB-C connector.
Be aware, it doesn't figure on any schematic/boardview; is the PI3USB32224B chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
threads.message:
I'm sorry. I just realized i post the wrong board model.
The board i'm working is 820-00845

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
threads.message:
What machine model?
That code is very strange...
Isn't 00045, or 00875?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
threads.message: Model: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
threads.message: Figure out why no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> first is it shorted to ground? Just fair warning, these ALWAYS end in dead CPU at some point, so it could have a faulty CPU as well or a CPU that fails weeks after you fix it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No PPBUS
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>.
If no result, is better to return it.
In fact, not worth to spend time on these boards at all.
Wiil finally end with dead CPU, or SSD...
